ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: One of the best classes I've taken at FES. You learn from the papers, the instructor & your peers. Presenting on the material forces you to learn it far better than you ever would just reading about it. The class does a great job applying the concepts covered to a broader range of environmental issues. It was a very low-risk way of engaging with the subject matter & improving my understanding of economics, CSR & behavior.

Fantastic course - I got a good sense of the field of environmental economics and the latest research. Through the presentations and discussions, I also developed an understanding of economic analysis, and how the research applies to our daily lives.
Great course, I really appreciate the seminar style of this class.
This was my favorite course this semester. Well run, well taught, and put the right amount of responsibility into student hands. I highly recommend this.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Flow of conversation and direction provided by Professor

The presentations really forced you to learn the material and practice your public speaking skills, while doing so in a very supportive environment. I never felt like I was being hung out to dry and both Kotchen & my classmates helped me to better understand the material.
The engaging discussions - people in this group truly wanted to learn and share information, which made the discussions a joy to participate in.
This class was a great opportunity for discussion of market mechanisms and behavioral economics in service of environmental goals.
All of the readings were applicable to any field of study. Going beyond the statistics and into applied statistics/consumer behavior is something that anyone can use.

This course was fantastically designed - the opportunity to really engage deeply with the primary literature was an excellent learning opportunity not just on the specific area of study, but on the skill and craft of reading journal articles.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The reading selection would be improved by including more field studies

Could actually benefit from more presentations, perhaps some partner presentations. Would love to have read some more case studies relating to the natural world; land management, conservation, species protection. The tuna case was the closest we got. I know it's harder to find relevant material in those areas, but there was an awful lot of energy material.
The format of student presentations may need some re-thinking - if you did all the reading then the summary-of-reading part of each presentation was unnecessary.
There need to be greater incentives to induce other people to read so that there is a livelier discussion.

I do think some kind of transparent accountability device would help guarantee more uniform preparation for the class. The tension is that with presentations designed to give a summary of the entire paper, it can feel redundant to read other articles (as they are typically well summarized for you by the presenter). This might be avoided by encouraging presenters to spend less time on overview/review, and more time on specific questions/concerns with the method and findings.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: n/a

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am not an energy person, so it could seem like a strange fit given the trends in the reading, but the concepts covered were so widely applicable that I found the class to be relevant to a broad range of fields and I especially enjoyed the behavioral economics components.
I took this course because I'm interested in water resources and how certain nudges can change consumer behaviors.
Great chance to engage with primary literature, and hone that skill.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Read studies and learn about behavior vis-a-vis "green programs"
To better understand the non-regulatory tools to encourage conservation and to better appreciate the individual and corporate motivations for applying those tools.
I wanted to get a better sense of environmental economics as a field of research.
I went during shopping period and it seemed like a really interesting topic. I also like the small seminar class format.
Same answer as question 17
Chance to work with Prof. Kotchen in a small class environment.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.

Absolutely. I have a better appreciation for the application of behavioral economics to voluntary environmental practices, and I also have a better sense of range and quality or research behind these ideas.
Absolutely.
Yes!
Yes
Very much so.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Forced to learn the material better
n/a

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: After the course, I can understand why it was called "green markets" but to novice eyes this is a bit misleading. The course considers a series of studies on various topics exploring how people respond to various stimuli to encourage (or discourage) green (or anti-green) behavior. This is not a course on any specific (green) market but the economic perspective of the general marketplace.

Take it. Low risk, high return. Not a lot of work for extremely valuable information. Kotchen is really in his element with this class & it's clear that he enjoys teaching it & participating in the discussion.
You get from this course what the group puts in (classic collective action problem?), so come prepared and be willing to share what you know.
Take it, and do the readings! It's a great course for anyone interested in environmental management without command-and-control regulation (which is pretty much everyone).
Stop being lazy. Do the readings and contribute in class. You're in grad school.
Do it!
